p: Using the early growth phase comprising the first few weeks of the major Zika epidemic, which began in June 2016, we estimated the scaling of growth parameter ( p) at 0.8 (95% CI: 0.2, 1.0) based on the first 5 weeks of the epidemic peak and 0.9 (95% CI: 0.7, 1.0) based on the first 8 weeks of epidemic growth ( Table 4). Thus, the growth scaling uncertainty for this epidemic, affecting a largely susceptible population, includes exponential growth dynamics (i.e., p = 1). Based on the GGM, we estimated R e at 3.3 (95% CI: 1.3, 5.3) and 3.4 (95% CI: 2.4, 4.7) based on 5 and 8 weeks of data of the early growth phase, respectively, and assuming a generation interval of 20 days (SD = 7.4 days) [ 40, 41].
